utterances: It's great to be back.
Here is this event that you write about.
This is Kirkwood Community College in Cedar Rapids.
Here's Senator Obama speaking to the crowd.

They are tired of the lack of progress on critical issues like health care and education and energy, and most of all, most of all, they are tired of a war that should have never been authorized and should have never been waged that has cost us dearly.
Okay.
There's Senator Obama campaigning this week.

And John, you write in your piece about this that's up on Slate, after this appearance a journalist colleague of yours turns to you and says, why isn't he killing her, meaning, not literally killing, but why isn't he doing much better than Senator Clinton?
That's right.
This colleague of mine, we'd been at some Clinton events the previous two days, and it was nothing like the kind of energy you got at the Obama event.
Now, I've seen the act before.
So it wasn't a surprise.
It was just the energy at the end when he leaves, the entire room is on its feet and chanting with him.
What is Senator Clinton like when she campaigns?
She must be doing something right.
She is.
She's very, very methodical.
She is - speaks with no notes.
There aren't a lot of jokes, but it is a thoroughly competent performance.

And as I say, you talk to the audience afterwards - I interviewed quite a lot of people in Iowa over the last three days - and they are a kind of moderately excited about her, and the Obama crowds are quite excited.
But then this question - so why isn't he doing much better than she is?
I don't think you really answer that in your piece.
You do raise the question.

Well, the answer may be in this one question that an Obama supporter who is warming up the crowd in Cedar Rapids asked before he arrived, and she said how many of you have never attended a caucus before?
And it felt like about half the room raised their hands.
And this is the challenge for Obama.

When you talk to Clinton voters or the folks who go to Clinton events, they almost always - and when I would I interview them - would say, well, I caucused last time for this person and I caucused the previous time for that person.
They are experienced caucus-goers.
And going to the caucus is not just like flipping a switch in an election booth.
You have to go and commit an evening and it's sometimes hard to find your caucus.
It's a bit of a chore.
And so the challenge for Obama is to get these people who are new to the process to decide on that cold January evening, January 3rd, to go in and go through this process and support him.
Well, the poll numbers do show they are fairly close in Iowa.
I mean, she's got a big lead nationally.
But in Iowa she doesn't.
Iowa polling - trying to poll people who are likely to go to the caucus is notoriously tricky and difficult.
And so it's close - and we know it's close from the numbers.
We know the numbers are imprecise.
But what we see on the ground is it looks really close also.
John Dickerson, chief political correspondent for Slate.com.
John, thank you again.
Thank you.
I'm Farai Chideya, and this is NEWS & NOTES.
Imagine, just imagine, that you're dealing with family stress, then your job tells you there's someone who can counsel you on the job - that person happens to be a chaplain.
Unusual?
Well, not so much anymore.
Chaplains are common in the military but not so often in corporate life.
Yet, Maceo Gray has been a workplace chaplain for more than a decade.
After working for 30 years as an electrical engineer, Gray left and went to divinity school.
He got his first chaplain's job at a poultry plant in Texas.
He's now the Midwest region vice president of a company called Marketplace Chaplains USA.
At the Lemke family home in Milwaukee, a gold star banner hangs in the front window.
That's the symbol that a family member has died at war.
Near the front door, there's a brown paper bag filled with Christmas gifts for Colleen and Greg Lemke's grandkids.
Their father, Jason Lemke, was supposed to be home this month on leave to watch his kids open the gifts.
His father Greg says the last time he spoke to his son he was thinking about ordering some new parts for his custom motorcycle.

Actually, he was planning on buying part of the motorcycle stuff before he got back, and I explained to him that I thought it'd be a bad idea, that he should just use all his time and energy to make sure he got back.
Jason Lemke wanted to enlist in the Army right after high school, but his parents talked him out of it.
Instead, he worked odd jobs, got married and raised two girls who are now seven and nine.
Years later, he divorced, joined the Army and after basic training he was sent to Fort Lewis, Washington, where he learned to speak Arabic.
Lemke's mother, Colleen, says she wasn't surprised when she found out her son was one of the few picked to learn the language.
He was very intelligent, so they thought that was a better position for him at the time.
He was going to be a translator.
Jason Lemke was deployed to Iraq in April of 2007 as part of the troop surge.
Greg Lemke says neither he nor his wife knew much about the area their son was stationed once he left Baghdad because he didn't tell them the truth.
He wasn't exactly a liar as a child; he was more truthful.
But he told us it was - eh, it's actually better here.
Now looking at the news clippings and that - that's actually the worst province in the country right now.
Lemke's parents say their son was only trying to protect them and keep them from worrying.
They say that's how he was with everyone.
Jason Lemke's friends say they remember him also as a constant jokester.
Jenny Wojack knew him in high school and they kept in touch over the years.
He had his times of seriousness, of course, but he would do anything to make anyone smile.
In high school he used to, like, make monkey faces and hop down the hallways at school and do the splits.
Or whatever he could do to make you laugh, he would do.
Dennis Fleischfresser is the father of one of Lemke's best friends.
As soon as you met him, he treated you like you were his best friend.
Obviously I'm not in his age group.
I'm in his dad's age group, but we got along like buddies, you know?
It wasn't like a father/son thing, or you know, I'm an old person you're a young person.
He was a very easy person to talk to and to like.
For NPR News, I'm LaToya Dennis in Milwaukee.
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
Good morning, I'm Steve Inskeep.
NPR's Jamie Tarabay was allowed a rare look inside the Interior Ministry.
And she filed this report.
Following standard procedure, a Western official escorting reporters pulls out his handgun before he enters the building.
(SOUNDBITE OF SECURITY CHECK)
Iraqi police at the front desk stiffen at the sight of strangers.
No one gets anywhere in this squalid 11-story building without a permit.
A senior Shiite police officer who calls himself Ali Kamal(ph) says the ministry is split into hostile armed camps.
(Through translator) The whole ministry is plagued.
Each floor represents a state of its own, a party or a certain group.
The Shiite parties want to get rid of the Sunni ones.
The Sunnis want to get rid of the Shiite ones.
The Kurdish parties want the Sunnis and the Shiites to fight each other.
They are all wrestling, and sometimes they even liquidate their rivals.
It's practically impossible to walk the dusty hallways of the building without the shadow of former Interior Minister Bayan Jabr looming overhead.
Jabr was leader of a Shiite paramilitary group.
And he brought thousands of militiamen into the ranks of the police force.
People here say he ran the ministry in a climate of fear, mistrust and corruption.
Jabr was removed from the Interior Ministry in May of last year.
He was given the government's finance portfolio.
His successor as interior minister is Jawad Bolani, who told NPR he's fired 16,000 employees of the ministry in the past year on charges of corruption and other crimes.
(Through Translator) It's a work in progress.
We have thousands of cases we're investigating.
We have a long way ahead of us to create a ministry that is balanced and structured fairly.
Bolani is a Shiite who's served in Iraq's air force for 15 years.
This is his first senior government position.
He's reputed to be independent of any of the major political parties, but observers fear the Interior Ministry's divisions run too deep to be bridged anytime soon.
It's a microcosm of Iraq and its conflict.
Again, police officer Ali Kamal.

(Through translator) There are different groups, and each one of them is holding a string, so what is happening now is no one can make decisions because everyone pulls the string in different directions.
They are not united.
Minister Bolani says he's focused on retraining, weeding out disloyal police and replacing commanders accused of kidnappings and killings.
(Through translator) There are negative things about government institutions like the Interior Ministry, but we shouldn't forget sacrifices made by the police and the suffering of their families.
More than 15,000 policemen, including both Sunnis and Shiites, have been killed in the violence here.
Jamie Tarabay, NPR News, Baghdad.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Guy Raz.
While summer doesn't officially end until later this month, you know as well as I do that the real end of summer is tomorrow.
The good news is there's lots to look forward to after Labor Day, from political drama on Capitol Hill, to one of the most anticipated fall seasons in pop music.
And this hour, we'll get a preview of what to expect this fall from the high court to high tech, from new fiction to the real-life stories on the sports field.
But first, we start with NPR's Washington correspondent Brian Naylor.
Brian, hello.
Hi, Guy.
The summer break is over.
Congress is back in session on Tuesday.
And right away, President Obama will address a rare joint session this Wednesday.
What can we expect?
